subject: tests: Fix API extension check
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-11-10 10:54:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/commit/7419ac2005437fb56080a23b7cb80adf4b865b11', 'message': "tests: Move and fix API extension check

The check for network extensions was not using a machine readable format
for output. This meant an API check could match on a substring, e.g. a
check for 'qos' would match on 'qos-specs'. In addition, no other
service uses extensions these days but we were checking for extensions
across all services. Fix both issues by switching our command invocation
to use JSON output and migrating the check function from the general
base class to the networking base class.

Change-Id: Idc6dc54503031ddf3e148f50ed53ad8898f7a7e3
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2023-11-12 10:35:52.000000000', 'files': ['openstackclient/tests/functional/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/commit/c251cb89a5cd11120106f6b0fb662b7daf815597', 'message': "tests: Fix API extension check

The check for extensions was not using a machine readable format for
output. This meant an API check could match on a substring, e.g. a check
for 'qos' would match on 'qos-specs'. Address this issue by switching
our command invocation to use JSON output and migrating the check
function from the general base class to the networking base class.

Change-Id: Idc6dc54503031ddf3e148f50ed53ad8898f7a7e3
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
tests: Fix API extension check

The check for extensions was not using a machine readable format for
output. This meant an API check could match on a substring, e.g. a check
for 'qos' would match on 'qos-specs'. Address this issue by switching
our command invocation to use JSON output and migrating the check
function from the general base class to the networking base class.

Change-Id: Idc6dc54503031ddf3e148f50ed53ad8898f7a7e3
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/06/900606/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @classmethod def is_extension_enabled(cls, alias, *, service='network'): """Ask client cloud if network extension is enabled""" extensions = cls.openstack( 'extension list --network', parse_output=True, ) return alias in [x['Alias'] for x in extensions]

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.2

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.2 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I10d6ba25b2284af88c72ab8dfc4e188c04bd1174

for the migration

This also fix py3.11 job by replacing libmysqlclient-dev with
libmariadb-dev-compat which is available for both ubuntu and debian.

Closes-Bug: #2043209
Change-Id: Iaba736d391ad5820de5f481d2c5bac1714dc0809
'}]
commit_message:
Use alembic alter_column for 35cb52c5553f migration

With latest sqlalchemy there is no alter attribute for the Column object

Thus, zun-db-manage upgrade fails with AttributeError. Instead of trying
to use SQLAlchemy for altering Column we should use alembic instead
for the migration

This also fix py3.11 job by replacing libmysqlclient-dev with
libmariadb-dev-compat which is available for both ubuntu and debian.

Closes-Bug: #2043209
Change-Id: Iaba736d391ad5820de5f481d2c5bac1714dc0809

commit_message:
Remove USE_PYTHON3 option

The USE_PYTHON3 option has been defaulted to true for
some time, and is no longer used. It was initially added
to enable adoption of python3, we have long moved past
needing to choose between python2 and python3, and
default on python3.

Also, since python2 is no longer supported, this makes
the code cleaner to read.

Change-Id: Ia9e62634c954446b0b47067fcdcd28cac49fbf4b

commit_message:
Add the setting of memcached servers to keystone_authtoken

In-process token cache is deprecated since 4.2.0 release
and may be removed. Add the setting of memcache for
the auth_token token cache.

Change-Id: I23ad1d9fb1b33160452ab353972fa1274cde363d

commit_message:
ignore dbcounter sub dirs

currently id you run devstack with the dbcounter service enabled
the created subdirs show up in git status

this change justs add them to .gitgnore

Change-Id: Iee48eb4e12ac22734c8a2c1dcbe0b92a0a387eaa

commit_message:
Fix openEuler support

openEuler 22.03 LTS support was removed from devstack in last
few months due to its libvirt version is too old and the CI job
always fail.

This Patch add a yum repository for libvirt7.2.0, and add the
related CI job to make sure its works well.

Change-Id: Ic507f165cfa117451283360854c4776a968bbb10

commit_message:
Add ability to add custom configuration for RabbitMQ

This implements a new variable  rabbitmq_custom_config  to
be able to place custom configuration to the rabbitmq.conf
e.g. to configure installed plugins

Change-Id: I952eefe646b00f60184f8d353f6f055bbdc4ac90

commit_message:
resource: Deprecate use of 'list_type'

Python has proper typing now, thus is would be nice to get away from
rolling our own. This is our first step in doing proper mapping, a la
SQLAlchemy 2.0 [1]. Our next step will be far more involved.

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/changelog/whatsnew_20.html#whatsnew-20-orm-declarative-typing

Change-Id: I2d85c0a7ca052172681ebc52ec69217741305592
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/25/900725/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import typing as ty links = resource.Body('links', type=ty.List[dict])
deleted_lines: links = resource.Body('links', type=list, list_type=dict)

commit_message:
WIP: Deprecate 'use_direct_get' parameter

Nothing is setting this to true, which means it's effectively a no-op
nowadays. Deprecate it.

WIP while I confirm this.

Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

subject: Wait for magnum endpoint before creating cluster templates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-11-09 14:40:01.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/magnum_resources.yml', 'examples/playbook.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_magnum/commit/42796583184ced367598c67cec74a8577688e0fd', 'message': 'Wait for magnum endpoint before creating cluster templates

Magnum playbook flushes handlers(that cause service restart) and then
it starts creating magnum resources right away.

In some cases(for ex. magnum tls upgrade job), magnum haproxy endpoint
is down before playbook flushes handlers. It means that after flushing
them, haproxy healthchecks need some time to rise magnum endpoint.
In this case, there is a high chance that playbook will try to connect
to magnum endpoint before haproxy marks it as alive.

To solve this issue, this patch implements an extra task to ensure
that magnum endpoint is reachable before playbook tries to reach it.

This patch also fixing linters issue in an example playbook to resolve
circular dependency.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins/+/896017
Change-Id: I36cf9f4b71daa107e27e966ebe25816c7bffa42a
(cherry picked from commit 9709e102df8b1a833012eaeffebc9f8f5a9d8f66)
'}]
commit_message:
Wait for magnum endpoint before creating cluster templates

Magnum playbook flushes handlers(that cause service restart) and then
it starts creating magnum resources right away.

In some cases(for ex. magnum tls upgrade job), magnum haproxy endpoint
is down before playbook flushes handlers. It means that after flushing
them, haproxy healthchecks need some time to rise magnum endpoint.
In this case, there is a high chance that playbook will try to connect
to magnum endpoint before haproxy marks it as alive.

To solve this issue, this patch implements an extra task to ensure
that magnum endpoint is reachable before playbook tries to reach it.

This patch also fixing linters issue in an example playbook to resolve
circular dependency.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins/+/896017
Change-Id: I36cf9f4b71daa107e27e966ebe25816c7bffa42a
(cherry picked from commit 9709e102df8b1a833012eaeffebc9f8f5a9d8f66)

subject: Fix deferred deletion for cloned volumes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-11-08 13:54:57.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_rbd.py', 'releasenotes/notes/bug-cbc9cc270fe3c9ca.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/a995cf86a0c8ab82f7d4fad69e4e312d6bbd5c6a', 'message': 'Fix deferred deletion for cloned volumes

If `enable_deferred_deletion=true` is set in Cinder, volumes will
be moved to "trash" and "purged" periodically in rbd pools.
However, for clone volumes (volumes created from other volumes),
enabling deferred deletion would cause these volume to fail
deletion. This happens because when, say, volume-B is created from
volume-A, it's done through copy on write. Cinder will first make
a snapshot of volume-A, and create volume-B as a clone of that
snapshot. When volume-B is deleted, the references in all its
parents should also be updated, and the parent snapshot should be
removed. However, the volume-A snapshot can only be deleted if the
child, volume-B, is gone (purged), which is not the case for
deferred deletion.

In order to fix this, when deferred deletion is enabled and a
volume is deleted, the references should be updated only **after**
the volume is actually deleted in `_trash_purge`, which is
executed periodically in cinder.

Closes-Bug: #1826115

Change-Id: I0e8a32b1052b2e82d78fb0bfbfb0bc463f3d84fa
Signed-off-by: Jing Geng <jgeng25@bloomberg.net>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix deferred deletion for cloned volumes

If `enable_deferred_deletion=true` is set in Cinder, volumes will
be moved to "trash" and "purged" periodically in rbd pools.
However, for clone volumes (volumes created from other volumes),
enabling deferred deletion would cause these volume to fail
deletion. This happens because when, say, volume-B is created from
volume-A, it's done through copy on write. Cinder will first make
a snapshot of volume-A, and create volume-B as a clone of that
snapshot. When volume-B is deleted, the references in all its
parents should also be updated, and the parent snapshot should be
removed. However, the volume-A snapshot can only be deleted if the
child, volume-B, is gone (purged), which is not the case for
deferred deletion.

In order to fix this, when deferred deletion is enabled and a
volume is deleted, the references should be updated only **after**
the volume is actually deleted in `_trash_purge`, which is
executed periodically in cinder.

Closes-Bug: #1826115

Change-Id: I0e8a32b1052b2e82d78fb0bfbfb0bc463f3d84fa
Signed-off-by: Jing Geng <jgeng25@bloomberg.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/11/900111/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | RBD driver `bug #1826115 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1826115>`_: Fixed the long-standing bug with deleting cloned volumes when deferred deletion is enabled by cleaning up references after the volume is purged in the periodic task.

commit_message:
Add common haproxy playbook from openstack-ansible repo

This was previously common-playbooks/haproxy-service-config.yml
in the openstack-ansible repo which was like that before collections
existed.

Moving this playbook into a collection allows it to be called
by FQCN from any other collection which might be useful when
extending openstack-ansible.

Change-Id: I41e18cbb83bd157cac371ebf311a279991218a83

commit_message:
get_from_shards(namespaces)

Change-Id: I9ec451033f303be89d0f08c057078be9216a737c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/90/900690/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: POLICY_KEY = 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index' namespaces = self._parse_namespaces( req, self._parse_listing_response(req, resp), resp) if not namespaces: # can't find ranges or there was a problem getting the ranges. # So return what we have. return resp req_limit = constrain_req_limit(req, CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT) req.headers[POLICY_KEY] = resp.headers.get(POLICY_KEY) objects = self._get_from_shards(req, namespaces, req_limit) resp.headers['X-Backend-Record-Type'] = 'object' resp.body = json.dumps(objects).encode('ascii') constrained = any(req.params.get(constraint) for constraint in ( 'marker', 'end_marker', 'path', 'prefix', 'delimiter')) if not constrained and len(objects) < req_limit: self.logger.debug('Setting object count to %s' % len(objects)) # prefer the actual listing stats over the potentially outdated # root stats. This condition is only likely when a sharded # container is shrinking or in tests; typically a sharded # container will have more than CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT objects # so any unconstrained listing will be capped by the limit and # total object stats cannot therefore be inferred from the # listing. resp.headers['X-Container-Object-Count'] = len(objects) resp.headers['X-Container-Bytes-Used'] = sum( [o['bytes'] for o in objects]) def _get_from_shards(self, req, namespaces, limit): raise HTTPServiceUnavailable(request=req) shard_resp.headers[POLICY_KEY] if shard_policy != req.headers[POLICY_KEY]: shard_policy, req.headers[POLICY_KEY]) raise HTTPServiceUnavailable(request=req) return objects
deleted_lines: resp = self._get_from_shards(req, resp) def _get_from_shards(self, req, resp): policy_key = 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index' if not (shard_listing_history or policy_key in req.headers): # We're handling the original request to the root container: set # the root policy index in the request, unless it is already set, # so that shards will return listings for that policy index. # Note: we only get here if the root responded with namespaces, # or if the namespaces were cached and the cached root container # info has sharding_state==sharded; in both cases we can assume # that the response is "modern enough" to include # 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index'. req.headers[policy_key] = resp.headers[policy_key] namespaces = self._parse_namespaces( req, self._parse_listing_response(req, resp), resp) if not namespaces: # can't find ranges or there was a problem getting the ranges. So # return what we have. return resp req_limit = constrain_req_limit(req, CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT) limit = req_limit return HTTPServiceUnavailable(request=req) shard_resp.headers[policy_key] if shard_policy != req.headers[policy_key]: shard_policy, req.headers[policy_key]) return HTTPServiceUnavailable(request=req) resp.headers['X-Backend-Record-Type'] = 'object' resp.body = json.dumps(objects).encode('ascii') constrained = any(req.params.get(constraint) for constraint in ( 'marker', 'end_marker', 'path', 'prefix', 'delimiter')) if not constrained and len(objects) < req_limit: self.logger.debug('Setting object count to %s' % len(objects)) # prefer the actual listing stats over the potentially outdated # root stats. This condition is only likely when a sharded # container is shrinking or in tests; typically a sharded container # will have more than CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT objects so any # unconstrained listing will be capped by the limit and total # object stats cannot therefore be inferred from the listing. resp.headers['X-Container-Object-Count'] = len(objects) resp.headers['X-Container-Bytes-Used'] = sum( [o['bytes'] for o in objects]) return resp

commit_message:
remove eventlet.tpool from rbd_utils

This change decouples the use of rbd thread pool proxying
from eventlet by explictly delegrating execution to
nova.utils.tpool_execute

Change-Id: Ie0ee61878fd286da60a2d379b0292148ec295b16

commit_message:
Add default to read_deleted in context's from_dict

this is follow-up to Ic94323658c89df1c1ff32f511ca23502317d0f00

currently the defaults in __init__ and from_dict of RequestContext
for read_deleted property are different:
- in __init__ it is 'no'
- in from_dict, it is effectively None.
And at the same time, this property is not allowed to be None.

As a result, the new _sanitize_context in oslo.messaging can not create
a sanitized context copy with error

read_deleted can only be one of 'no', 'yes' or 'only', not None

Related-Bug: #2030976
Change-Id: Ifb660688c590fb1c32cbe0ae03e0ea444f19cbb8
(cherry picked from commit 785f23b3bc219c554698fe54fbd478ef04fc9229)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/55/893255/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: read_deleted=values.get('read_deleted', 'no'),
deleted_lines: read_deleted=values.get('read_deleted'),

commit_message:
veth: Remove support for EL8 / network-scripts

We no longer support EL8 or network-scripts.

Debian systems never used this role, so also removing those tasks.

commit_message:
[Fullstack] Drop all linuxbridge scenarios from fullstack tests

As we discussed on the Neutron CI meeting on 7.11.2023 (it was video
meeting, no strict logs stored) [1], to save some time in the fullstack
job execution we want to stop running all the Linuxbridge related
tests/scenarios in fullstack test suite.
Linuxbridge is experimental feature now, not really fully supported by
the Neutron team so we are allowed to do so in this case.
This patch is doing exactly that. There are no any Linuxbridge agent
related tests/scenarios.

Support for Linuxbridge in the Fullstack framework wasn't however
removed completely. It is like that because of 2 reasons:

* there is one DHCP agent related test which tests different segments
  and is using Linuxbridge agent on one of the fake nodes,
* maybe there will be at some point need to have some Linuxbridge agent
  test there so the infrastructure for that is still available, it won't
  cause any issues while it's (almost) not used currently.

[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/meetings/neutron_ci/2023/neutron_ci.2023-11-07-15.00.html

Change-Id: I709c477f66ada037e47ec9abc7fbed1d1a238d20
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/06/900406/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from neutronclient.common import exceptions ('Linux Bridge Agent', { 'l2_agent_type': constants.AGENT_TYPE_LINUXBRIDGE})] if self.l2_agent_type == constants.AGENT_TYPE_LINUXBRIDGE: # Linuxbridge agent don't support update of segmentation_id for # the network so this should raise an exception self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self._update_segmentation_id, network) else: self._update_segmentation_id(network)

commit_message:
Drop until-complete  flag for db purge

Flag --until-complete is not valid for the nova-manage db purge command,
it is working only for archive_deleted_rows [1]. Suposedly it was a
copy/paste mistake to keep the flag in place.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/cli/nova-manage.html#db-archive-deleted-rows

Change-Id: I7be8c41bd52b955d83c4452e67ef323abe00969e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova refs/changes/29/899129/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Create mono repo for sunbeam charms

Currently each sunbeam charm is in its own repo. This approach
is going to be replaced by having a single monolithic repo that
will contain all the sunbeam charms.

Required-By: Ie72e31f8375371b87c97d9264aa4b92344efa0d9
Change-Id: I79e5efca77a49b1cd2b0706d37a39cbbab4a19dd

commit_message:
Containerized sshd does not work with older PAM

sshd containers don't let logins on some systems with older
PAM library because /proc/self/loginuid is not always readable
or writeable. Examples of possible failures on such systems are
erroneous cold and live migrations.

This change is derivied form
Ic14255b042ceedcff536c062bdcba00502af7a87
and takes the same approch as was done for crond in
Id384780e8394b40a91761e7fbbc0f8e44263d681

Resolves: rhbz#2248873
Change-Id: I592c1182f409ebc486fb33429c3608a67d8ac3e9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/25/900525/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Disable GLOBAL_VENV

Devstack recently introduced the functionality to use a single venv [1]
but some devstack plugins in telemetry project are not compatible with
this change.

This disables the option as a short term workaround.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/558930

Change-Id: Ic300c90a19ca348b8316e63190e60b67f6b73ad3
Story: 2010912
Related-Bug: 2031639
Related-Bug: 2034891
(cherry picked from commit 8de7585f374097bcb4910bfbed34b6c721490db9)

commit_message:
Fix setting kolla_admin_openrc_cacert

Kolla Ansible renamed kolla_internal_fqdn_cacert to
kolla_admin_openrc_cacert in Victoria, after which we no longer set the
variable correctly in globals.yml. This would lead to a missing
OS_CACERT in admin-openrc.sh and public-openrc.sh.

This change fixes the issue by renaming the relevant Kayobe variables to
match and passing through the correct variable. Backwards compatibility
is provided until the end of the deprecation period.

kolla_public_openrc_cacert -> kolla_external_fqdn_cacert
kolla_admin_openrc_cacert -> kolla_internal_fqdn_cacert

Story: 2010486
Task: 47054

Change-Id: I9e1cc20579cf80525d6ef732a1aac99a65bc171b
Co-Authored-By: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 95729405a38e6292a828c26347406e70132136b2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kayobe refs/changes/84/900584/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: kolla_public_openrc_cacert: kolla_admin_openrc_cacert:
deleted_lines: kolla_external_fqdn_cacert: kolla_internal_fqdn_cacert:

subject: Generate local Kolla Ansible config in check mode
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-11-10 10:13:04.000000000', 'files': ['kayobe/tests/unit/cli/test_commands.py', 'kayobe/cli/commands.py', 'releasenotes/notes/check-mode-local-config-3f8a4ba231a32c1f.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kayobe/commit/a8be8fe89ec6e54603c632400d30b44c4a7bdd2b', 'message': 'Generate local Kolla Ansible config in check mode

If running a command in check mode such as

    kayobe overcloud service deploy --check

Kayobe does not generate the local configuration for Kolla Ansible. This
can lead to an inaccurate result when comparing with the remote
configuration, if there are changes in kayobe-config.

For example:

* Run kayobe overcloud service deploy
* Change a file in etc/kayobe/kolla
* Run kayobe overcloud service deploy --check --diff

We would expect that the changed file results in a diff against the
remote config. However there is no diff displayed.

This change fixes the issue by always generating the local Kolla Ansible
config, even in check mode.

Change-Id: Ic1dd075076ea186b0928bba1a235605c0cd2ec71
Story: 2010526
Task: 47132
(cherry picked from commit 2c0f705e7acab5691591c215e40dea707d12da15)
'}]
commit_message:
Generate local Kolla Ansible config in check mode

If running a command in check mode such as

    kayobe overcloud service deploy --check

Kayobe does not generate the local configuration for Kolla Ansible. This
can lead to an inaccurate result when comparing with the remote
configuration, if there are changes in kayobe-config.

For example:

* Run kayobe overcloud service deploy
* Change a file in etc/kayobe/kolla
* Run kayobe overcloud service deploy --check --diff

We would expect that the changed file results in a diff against the
remote config. However there is no diff displayed.

This change fixes the issue by always generating the local Kolla Ansible
config, even in check mode.

Change-Id: Ic1dd075076ea186b0928bba1a235605c0cd2ec71
Story: 2010526
Task: 47132
(cherry picked from commit 2c0f705e7acab5691591c215e40dea707d12da15)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kayobe refs/changes/87/900587/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes an issue where local configuration generation would be skipped when running in check mode. This would lead to Kolla Ansible checking with stale configuration. See `story 2010526 <https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2010526>`__ for details.

commit_message:
Always disable libvirt default network

Currently, autostart for libvirt default network is disabled only when
this network is active during nova playbook execution.
It's an incorrect behavior because in some cases this network may not be
active from the beginning.
Autostart should be always disabled to ensure that this network will not
be unexpectedly marked as active in the future(during package upgrade,
host reboot etc.).

Closes-Bug: #2042369
Change-Id: I697234bda1601b534ce1b6ab186fa98f83179ee8
(cherry picked from commit feb15af75b1d38fdfa2c670c55a6d0f4c95c5ad7)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova refs/changes/92/900192/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Get information about libvirt default network command: "virsh net-info default" register: default_net_info when: default_net_info.stdout | regex_search('Autostart:\s+yes') when: default_net_info.stdout | regex_search('Active:\s+yes')
deleted_lines: - name: Check for libvirt default network shell: "virsh net-list | awk '/default/'" register: default_net failed_when: false when: default_net.stdout.find('default') != -1 when: default_net.stdout.find('default') != -1

subject: dev: Improve error checking for config check functions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-11-10 10:14:37.000000000', 'files': ['dev/functions'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kayobe/commit/c33dcfbee4db715a175ccce4d928036f0c40c94e', 'message': "dev: Improve error checking for config check functions

Various functions in the development/testing scripts rely on 'kayobe
configuration dump' to extract the value of flags. If this command fails
for any reason, we should exit the script. Currently, some places we
continue and return 1, since we check the output against the string
'true'.

The to_bool helper function handles failure by checking for a valid
boolean output, so let's use that everywhere.

Change-Id: I3a5a43fef9c3d68d0db02be12b9f892c437e513d
(cherry picked from commit 89fc4fa2792ef256ff7624559a8ea8e2ee2f13fc)
"}]
commit_message:
dev: Improve error checking for config check functions

Various functions in the development/testing scripts rely on 'kayobe
configuration dump' to extract the value of flags. If this command fails
for any reason, we should exit the script. Currently, some places we
continue and return 1, since we check the output against the string
'true'.

The to_bool helper function handles failure by checking for a valid
boolean output, so let's use that everywhere.

Change-Id: I3a5a43fef9c3d68d0db02be12b9f892c437e513d
(cherry picked from commit 89fc4fa2792ef256ff7624559a8ea8e2ee2f13fc)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kayobe refs/changes/91/900591/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: to_bool "$ipa_build_images" to_bool "$ironic_enabled" to_bool "$overcloud_dib_build_host_images" } function is_cinder_enabled { flag="$(run_kayobe configuration dump --host controllers[0] --var-name kolla_enable_cinder)" to_bool "$flag"
deleted_lines: [[ $ipa_build_images =~ ^true$ ]] [[ $ironic_enabled =~ ^true$ ]] [[ $overcloud_dib_build_host_images =~ ^true$ ]]function is_cinder_enabled { flag="$(run_kayobe configuration dump --host controllers[0] --var-name kolla_enable_cinder)" to_bool "$flag" }
